title: Periodic Action
intent: Replace continuous or one-time actions with periodic ones to reduce load, cost, and risk while maintaining effectiveness.

triz_principle.name: Periodic Action
triz_principle.definition: Instead of continuous action, use periodic or pulsed actions; adjust frequency as needed.

problem_understanding.core_contradiction: We want constant control and availability, but continuous operation is expensive and fragile.
problem_understanding.why_this_hurts: Always-on processes consume resources, amplify noise, and make systems harder to stabilize and reason about.
typical_signals: processes running even when nothing changes

solution_logic.core_idea: Act at meaningful intervals instead of continuously.
solution_logic.key_rule: Choose frequency based on business impact, not technical convenience.
solution_logic.how_it_resolves_the_contradiction: The system stays responsive where it matters while reducing unnecessary work and noise.

consulting: scheduled decision checkpoints instead of constant reviews
periodic steering meetings with clear agendas
time-boxed audits instead of continuous scrutiny
software_engineering: batch processing instead of constant polling
scheduled jobs triggered by change volume
architecture: scheduled reconciliation instead of real-time syncing
enterprise_sap: periodic data synchronization instead of continuous replication
batch-based mass changes with controlled windows

anti_patterns: batch sizes that grow without limits

use_when: continuous processing brings little added value
real-time is not a true business requirement

diagnostic_questions: Which actions truly require real-time execution?
What is the acceptable delay for business value?
Where could batching reduce noise and cost?

example.before: System continuously polls downstream systems for changes.
example.after: Changes are collected and processed in controlled periodic batches.
